examples: He mouthed his opinions on the subject at the meeting.

definitions.definition: To represent (words or sounds) by making the actions of speech , but silently, without producing sound; to frame .
examples: The prompter mouthed the words to the actor, who had forgotten them.

definitions.definition: To move the mouth, with or without sound; to form (air or words) with the mouth, with or without sound.
To utter with a voice that is overly loud or swelling.
To exit at a mouth (such as a river mouth)
To pick up or handle with the lips or mouth, but not chew or swallow .
examples: The fish mouthed the lure, but didn't bite.

definitions.definition: To take into the mouth; to seize or grind with the mouth or teeth; to chew; to devour.
To form or cleanse with the mouth; to lick, as a bear licks her cub.
To form a mouth or opening in.

secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To represent (words or sounds) by making the actions of speech , but silently, without producing sound; to frame .
( transitive , intransitive ) To move the mouth, with or without sound; to form (air or words) with the mouth, with or without sound.
( ambitransitive ) To utter with a voice that is overly loud or swelling.
To exit at a mouth (such as a river mouth)
( transitive ) To pick up or handle with the lips or mouth, but not chew or swallow .
To take into the mouth; to seize or grind with the mouth or teeth; to chew; to devour.
To form or cleanse with the mouth; to lick, as a bear licks her cub.
To form a mouth or opening in.
( sheep husbandry ) To examine the teeth of.
